Chitinophaga niabensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil collected in Niabe, Senegal, Africa. It belongs to the genus Chitinophaga, which is part of the phylum Bacteroidetes.

Chitinophaga niabensis is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. It is rod-shaped and motile, with gliding motility. The cells are approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.5-4.0 μm in length.

This species is capable of hydrolyzing chitin, a structural polysaccharide found in the exoskeletons of arthropods and cell walls of fungi. This ability to degrade chitin is a characteristic feature of the Chitinophaga genus.

Chitinophaga niabensis grows optimally at a temperature of 30°C and a pH range of 6.0-8.0. It can utilize a variety of carbohydrates as carbon sources for growth, including glucose, fructose, and cellobiose.

The genome of Chitinophaga niabensis has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to the soil environment. This information contributes to our understanding of the ecological roles and potential applications of this bacterial species in natural and engineered systems.
